segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Welcome to the annual DEFCON convention. This meeting was held in exciting Las Vegas, Nevada from July 9th through the 11th, 1999.
This is meeting number 33, IPv6. What, when, where, how, why?
...is running out of space, and because it comes down to the Goldilocks problem of Class C being too small, Class A being too big, and Class B being just right.
And they try to aggregate, aggregating like sticking together blocks of Class C and then have the router route it together.
Classic center domain routing. But that's only a temporary fix because our routing tables are getting smaller.
Yeah? IPv5. Yes, actually, that's I think on the next page. Yeah, that's on the next page. Yes, there was.
IPv5 was a, actually it's in use, it's a stream transport protocol made by the IETF, the Internet Engineering Task Force.
That's what makes most of the protocols. But IPv5 is out there, so they called it IPv6.
Actually, competing proposals were IPv7, 8, and 9, and so I don't know what the next one will be.
But they had, the routing tables were getting too big and too complex to try to route all these things because everybody wanted a Class B address.
We have more than 256 machines, we want a Class B address.
So we need, the other thing, why do we need a new version of the protocol is we need address renumbering.
They decided, the IETF and some other people were figuring that we needed address renumbering.
Whenever we moved from one provider to another, we'd have to renumber all of our addresses and nobody wanted to do that manually anymore.
In the original days, it was all set up, the routing tables were just manually entered into the computer in the Unix boxes.
But the mobility of the computers and the computers are switching from one to another.
I mean, my Palm Pilot has an IPv4 stack.
Everything is getting more and more connected to the Internet, your dishwasher, your microwaves on the Internet.
But they decided that they needed more and more stuff and to renumber the addresses.
We needed to get real-time traffic because in order to get real-time traffic, say I wanted to get video on demand,
I could just go and start watching Terminator 2 over the Internet and I want it not to lag every time.
I mean, real audio and real video is bad enough.
We needed some auto-configuration, meaning that we wanted to be able to take a computer out of the box,
plug it in the wall and have it automatically figure out where it is, who its neighbors are, where its routers are, the nearest router, etc.
And of course, why we're all here is they needed more security.
Currently right now, IPsec or IP security, which is about the last half of the talk here, is on IP security in general.
They needed to add that in, so they put it as a mandatory feature.
So what is it? As I said, it's a complete overhaul.
They didn't just extend it. They completely redid the headers.
It started in 1992 through the IETF process.
Other protocols were developed. Proposals were sent out.
You know, the standard protocol development of IETF.org.
They wanted to have a larger address space, obviously, because of this.
Because they wanted to be able to waste some space in order to make our routing tables easier.
Right now, you've got to have everything just right on the classes.
They wanted to make sure the mobility. They've got mobile IP for v6.
Different traffic classes, FTP, email, bulk, versus, for example, real-time video.
They wanted to make sure security, or at least authentication, was part of everything available.
But you wanted to make sure that IPv4, there wasn't a day in which,
all right, at once, we're going to all convert over to IPv6.
So we've got to have some way to transition, and I'll talk about transitioning.
We now have, instead of 32-bit addresses, we're now going to 128-bit addresses.
So that is a fully qualified internet address with, well, obviously made up,
but that's how long these addresses are going to be.
So they needed to have shortcuts, so they were able to, like,
if you have a bunch of zeros, you could squish it and drop off some of the leading zeros
and have double colons and other stuff like that.
But for the most part, people don't need to know where addresses are.
I mean, unless you're doing promiscuous mode and want to find out who's doing what.
But they wanted to put more emphasis on the domain name servers,
which are also going to be changed because you can't have,
and that will be discussed later, you can't just have an A record,
Okay, so some hosts can have more than one interface.
Before, it's like I have an IP address, there's my box.
I have another IP address, here's my other box.
Now, mobility can be, we can have a box connected to multiple providers.
We can have a site that's connected to MCI and Sprint,
so when Sprint goes down, MCI can take over without having to renumber stuff.
We can add mobility, so if I move from Virginia out to here,
it's automatically renumbered and I don't have to try to retype in the thing.
In fact, even on campus, moving from one building to another,
moving from one subnet to another requires a renumbering manually.
Going through and even rebooting the machine, it fits Windows sometimes.
The boundaries are no longer fixed.
We have what we call prefixes.
So you see right there, the 3FFE0900, colon, colon,
and then a bunch of zeros out, slash 24.
And that means the first 24 bits or 3FFE09 is the prefix,
kind of like your subnet address.
But that's, and I'll show a picture of how the routing will actually work.
Since the addresses can be renumbered,
everybody has a lifetime of addresses.
There's an address, how long it's valid for, and how long it's preferred for.
So the addresses can be renumbered for whatever reason.
So about 136 years maximum or infinity,
and you renumber it a preferred address time before the new one is sought.
But they'll have different ones so that you'll know when to renumber.
You'll need to know that they've been divided up into a couple of categories.
So why did they choose 128 bits and not, say, 64 bits?
I mean, 2 to 64 is an astronomical number.
In fact, 2 to 28, I think, is about 6.7 times 10 to the 23rd addresses
per square meter of the Earth's surface.
I mean, if you heard Bruce's talk yesterday, 2 to the 128 is almost uncountable.
So why would we need 6.7 times 10 to the 23rd addresses per square meter?
It's more effective to have the wasting blocks of addresses
in order to get our router tables easier and faster.
So let me show you how they calculated 128 bits.
Okay, so this is the only formula in the talk,
but Dr. Christian Kutema, who is a highly respected member of the IETF and the IESG,
developed this H number, and he said the log of the number of addresses
over the number of bits is your percent efficiency.
So if we have 10 bits in 1,024 hosts, about 0.30.
If you take the log of 1024 and divide it by 10, this should be right.
So they've estimated by looking at large networks in IPv4 right now,
the way it is, that H is between 0.22 and 0.26.
Well, if H is 0.22 to 0.26 and only 32 bits in IPv4,
if we had the perfect efficiency.
Now what they want to do is they want to connect everybody around the world to IP.
They want to have a computer for every person on the planet,
sooner be it 10 billion people in each of those,
up to 100,000 computers if they wanted to have everything else on there,
and who knows, there's objects that aren't with people.
So they calculated that as somewhere between 57 and 68 bits.
So instead of limiting themselves to 64 bits, they went to 128 bits.
So let me explain some new concepts to you.
Unicast we've seen, that's from one to one,
uni being one, goes from one interface to another.
It's a standard address that we use right now.
Multicast we've seen right now, that's one to multiple interfaces.
This is a class D address in IPv4.
There is no broadcast anymore in IPv6 when it comes around,
So if I'm sitting at my site in Kansas,
I want to find out where the nearest machine is to a group of similar machines.
So if I want to find where CNN is, CNN may have a site in Atlanta and London and Moscow,
but my computer needs to know where the nearest one is.
So what it does is it just searches out through the router table,
a ring at a time, until it finds the nearest server.
And it's a new feature in IPv6 called anycast.
So basically any machine within a certain group of machines will be found.
Let's talk about some link-local, site-local, and global addresses,
and then I'll actually show you in the next couple of slides
what an address, how it will be broken up.
So link-local, all machines on, if I just had an Ethernet segment,
and I wanted to have all the machines on there,
that would be called link-local machines.
They're not connected to the Internet.
They're kind of like your 10.0.0.0 machines for the Class A and other ones.
You just set it out of the box, and away it goes.
They have site-local, obviously global, but they have site-local,
where you'd have different addresses for a group of machines that are just called site.
Now what's a site? Is it a single campus,
or is it a company that's spread out over the world and call it a site?
So there's different addresses that are laid out.
In the next slide, let me show you the different percentage of addresses.
And you can see the inefficiency and for future expansion.
Because right now, the way they've allocated it,
global unicast, which is from one to one through the global,
is one-eighth of the address space. That's it.
And that's one of the biggest chunks.
The other biggest chunk is geographic-based unicast,
which is based off of GPS or any other kind of address
that's based on where the machine is.
They've got things in here for IPX, multicast addresses, link-local,
which is what I said on a particular link, site-local and others.
That accounts for about 30% of the address space.
And that includes every single global unicast.
So another 70% of addresses is not assigned.
So theoretically, you could branch this off into space at some point
and maybe have IP on other planets or the moon and stuff like that.
So let me show you what a different...
A global unicast address is kind of like the common one,
which is what most people use.
And I took 128 bits and divided it up into...
But the IETF divided it into format prefix, which is the third.
There's 3 bits on the left down there,
which kind of tells whether it's a global-based machine or an IPX,
You've got TLAs, NLAs, SLAs, and the interface ID.
Now, the TLA is kind of like the overall global providers,
while the NLA is for particular sites.
So a TLA would be something like Sprint.
The next-level Aggregator could be University.
instead of giving out little subnets of 256 or 1,000, 24 bits each,
each University is given a fixed format prefix,
a fixed TLA and a fixed NLA,
so that each University can give out SLAs any way they want to.
Well, that's 16 bits right in there that they can give out per network,
so up to 65,000 networks for every site.
Now, the interface ID is, you take the Ethernet card
and you run through some IEEE shifting around.
You basically take your MAC address, split it apart, put some stuff,
put a couple bits in the middle, FFF, E, and zeros in there,
flip a couple bits, and you'll come up with your interface address.
So that's how your addresses are calculated,
basically off your MAC address, since most people now have Ethernet.
But if not, there's other ways of getting the 64-bit.
So the 64-bit is just for a machine, much less in the site and all that.
Let me show you now the header.
Our old IP header is gone.
They still have the version number where it's supposed to be,
but now they've got some different things in there.
We have flows and priorities and class.
Priority used to be class and flow label.
That's like saying every frame of Terminator 2 will have a unique flow label,
so you can know what frame is coming through,
and you'll know that this is a Terminator 2 film that's going to this address,
needs real-time video so that the routers can go through to see the header,
figure out that it's real-time traffic,
not even have to look at the whole packet and send it on.
So just with a few bits.
You'll notice that there's no IP options anymore.
And I'll cover how those are covered, but there's no IP options.
It's a way that they just stick it all in there.
Payload length, you can have up to 64K in a packet.
However, there's ways of getting more in there.
Next header is kind of like an IP.
It says, you know, the next header is TCP.
Hop limit is not time to live because people,
hop limit is you decrement one every time you go through a router
because you used to have time to live,
and no longer are routers one, you know.
Every router takes less than a second.
Because TTL used to be the number of seconds that it was at a router.
And there's your source and destination bits.
But let me show you in...
Payload length is 16 bits, but if you put the length to zero,
you can have something called a jumbogram.
and in other words, going toward that,
it makes more efficiency to send larger packets.
But they haven't really addressed this,
but I'm not really sure what a ping of death would be
with a jumbogram of four gig.
I don't know whether it's just like, you know,
You know, that's the kind of vision they see.
But, you know, from a security point of view,
I'm kind of wondering, well, it's legal to send a four gig packet,
but that's a serious mail bomb or packet bomb.
There's different, instead of using options,
they've got headers for authentication and ESP
and stuff like that, fragment and destination,
so that every packet doesn't have to be looked at until the end.
They can just, if they want a hop by hop header, they could.
But, for instance, using a fixed size header without the options
and no fragmentation, if you need fragmentation,
You allow it, but for the most part, they won't have it.
So you don't have to look at the fragmentation.
So the routers will be at least 40% faster
with just a fixed size header in experiments that have been done.
You know, you stick an IPv4 and then a TCP and away you go.
The router header will say it's TCP.
Or the next header is routing, which will then say it's a fragment.
The next thing is a fragment will say authentication.
You know, just chain the headers straight on down.
This is ripped out of RFC 1883.
Let me show you about routing.
In routing, you have, if I'm at router X,
we have variable length subnet masks.
So now, you know, your classes are A, B, and C,
and everything is kind of laid out.
Your routers are laid out with, they find the longest prefix.
So remember that slash 24, what that means?
That means that the first 24 bits of the 128 bits
So it's going to say prefix 1 and router 1,
Here's two examples on the bottom.
If I have an IPv6 address,
what happens, as you can see with the bold,
is it will take the first,
the router will say, well, here, let me show you over here.
It'll go there, to the 24 bits,
because it sees and matches the first as many bits as it can
Whereas this one, that router 1 will be matched
with some router 4, because it's up to R,
because these 64 bits are matched, so it'll send it to 4.
that the router 1 will be taken
because it matches only up to the 24 bits.
And so the longer the way down the chain,
the more easy it'll be to get to the router,
so that the longer addresses will go there.
And that's what's called variable-length subnet masks.
So any network can have any number of,
you can have a slash 24, slash 25,
So you can see how your networks can be completely aggregated
Mobility, one of my favorite topics,
the ability to move from one to another.
We've got mobile IPv6, which is IP for mobility.
They've actually got mobile IPv4, they've done experiments on it.
They've got mobile ad hoc networks,
where a bunch of us get together with our laptops
and turn them on, and with infrared wireless links,
we now have a system set up to play whatever game we're playing,
The computer should be able to, that's what they want to do,
you should be able to turn it on,
and have everybody see who's out there,
But not just in a room, but anywhere.
So if there's a router port or a network access point in the corner,
I should be able to turn on my machine,
it should be able to say,
wait, there's a wireless link in the corner,
my IP address is this, my nearest router is this,
and automatically configure the computer to go with that.
My concern is, well, I went to an IETF meeting in Washington, D.C. once,
and they were kind of like, well, we'll put off security until later.
And that's what really concerns me,
is these same attacks have been coming over and over,
and you know that this is going to be a problem.
But for mobility, they've got address space now to move around.
You don't have to keep just one IP address.
You could have any number of IP addresses.
And anything can be on the internet now.
Co-located means that it's going to another place through agents.
Neighbor Discovery is what I talked about there,
about being able to just turn it on, figure out what the prefix is,
what the MTU, maximum minimum transfer unit is,
or maximum transfer unit, figure out the hop length.
Duplicate address detection, you know, is my box already out there?
Does somebody already have my IP number or not?
So I've kind of answered the questions of what it is,
and now I try to figure out, well, who's using it?
You know, I like my IPv4. I don't care.
But right now, it is in universities.
People are starting to come around to testing this out.
And I'll go through later what the mechanism is,
how you're going to transfer over, what the plan is.
There are IPv6 stacks out there for Unix.
And Windows 2000, they said at one point,
does anybody know whether they'll be in there or not?
I don't know, but they're trying to establish it in there.
In fact, one of the ways to get transition is to use dual stacks,
But that's on the next slide.
So there's a couple of ways.
How would we transfer this over?
Well, there's the 6-Bone, which is similar to the M-Bone,
If you hop on and you want to see NASA's space shuttle downlink,
you can get an address on the M-Bone and go through that.
But they've got different islands of IPv6.
You know, University A has an IPv6 network.
University B has an IPv6 network.
And they want to talk to each other over the global IPv4.
So they use, through the IPv4c, they connect it through gateways,
which translate IPv6 to IPv4, you know,
unwraps the packets and packs it back up and sends it across.
You can either have dual stacks, which are one machine,
you have two different stacks to handle the packets.
You know, if an IPv4 packet comes in, it knows that.
If it's an IPv6 packet, it goes with that.
Or you can have tunneling, which they place one packet inside of another.
Just like you encapsulate the TCP inside of an IP,
you encapsulate an IPv4 packet inside of an IPv6 packet.
This can be done, but it's inefficient because now,
if you've got, if the only way I can reach by the other IPv6
is through these sets of tunnels, where it may just be the machine right next door
and I may have to go all the way around the Internet to find my next-door machine.
It's inefficient, but they're trying to put it together.
Okay, well, that's a general overview of IPv6,
and I'll come into more detail later.
Let's switch gears here and talk about,
DEF CON's about security, security for IP.
Now, IP security, some of you haven't heard of it, IPsec.
They've got different headers, a different,
you have an authentication header and an encapsulating security payload.
Actually, this will work for IPv4 as well.
But for IPv6, authentication is required for every transaction,
except when you put in like a null authentication,
which I figured that one out.
They put security associations and tells which, you know,
this machine is using DES to talk to this connection.
This machine, you know, we're using IDEA to talk to this machine.
And Bellaventa wrote a paper a couple years ago,
which goes through, and they fixed a lot of the problems that he mentions.
But the problem areas for the IP security protocols
and their references is in the back.
But the IETF had IPsec working on it,
various crypto techniques to put it in there.
You can use, the reason why they have,
you may ask, why didn't they just have a crypto header?
You may ask, why didn't they just have a crypto header?
The reason why is because when they developed this,
you know, I am really Dr. Byte coming from Las Vegas,
they wouldn't allow encryption through their country.
So you could have it so that people could just use authentication,
or you could use authentication and encryption,
or you could just use encryption.
But that's why, the selected use of it.
A little bit about the authentication header,
Basically, a base level is MD5,
but you can add other stuff in there.
They've got, for those security associations,
you can say, well, I'm using this type of authentication protocol,
or even a new protocol that's been developed,
and you just stick it right in there.
I'll show you the header format in a later slide.
DES is the CBC, is the ESP base thing,
but we can stick in any other kind of encryption on there.
So this is the header format ripped out of the RFC,
where everything is based off of header chaining.
The next header is this and the other.
There's a listing, well, it was through IANA,
but now it's gone up, Postel has passed away,
so they shifted it over to somebody else.
But there's different things, the length of the header,
Your index is basically a 32-bit number,
you can have up to, I guess, 4 billion connections.
It says, you know, connection number one
has got this type of authentication header,
so it knows which connection is going to which machines.
If I have a host-based authentication
where my machines are talking to each other,
there's lots of attacks you can do,
and Belvin describes those in his paper.
Dr. Belvin describes how you can,
if you're using the same key for everybody on the same host,
then there's attacks that can be done.
is done with just another security association
and just various sets of data in here
that may have keys and other such stuff.
I have a feeling I forgot to put in the next header chain,
but for the most part, that's that.
So what is this security association
what kind of security are we going to have for this connection?
Let's make a record or a structure
or whatever else you want to call it,
that says what security we're going to use,
what authentication method, what authentication keys,
which encryption method are we going to use
and which encryption keys are we going to use,
how long the key should last,
And there's an index into the database
that determine which things are in there
And you can use different ones for different connections
and different machines and different sessions
and other such stuff like that.
there's two pages of, two slides of,
which was a great paper where he listed,
you know, the ESP provides confidentiality,
You know, like I didn't send that stock certificate, no.
because if you send a, you know,
a telnet session is one character at a time,
so you encapsulate one character in a packet,
so if you know if it's the same host key,
if everybody's using the same keys,
if you ever read Tom's tax paper
that's firewalls can be brought around
I mean IPsec is supposed to solve all these,
but there's still plenty of thing out there.
let's see how we're going to help solve some of this.
You know, we want to have,
you don't want to have just encryption without integrity,
because you can change anything in there,
you want to have per user,
you want to have different keys for that.
you want just a general overall attack
they'll send them a plain text
and they'll encrypt something in back,
or you'll send something in cipher text
and they'll send it back in plain,
they'll send an error message in plain text.
because then that helps you with the cryptanalysis,
but plain text to plain text,
and cipher text to cipher text.
That's what you want to do.
DNS, I'll talk about DNS later,
because that's going to have to be changed with all this.
It'll have to be added on.
No longer will you be able to send an IP address
DNS security is a separate working group,
where your DNS stuff will be.
to be able to try to pose your DNS servers.
we have, the IETF has standards coming out.
You can split the headers for restricted countries,
my main, when I went to IETF,
it's a catch-all for all other things.
Let me just stick IPSEC on there,
or we'll figure out security later.
Let me just design a protocol,
but we're sticking security on as an afterthought.
You cannot stick security on as an afterthought.
You've got to build it in.
And look where that's leading us.
How do we do key exchanges?
You know, if everybody's doing authentication,
now there are keys flying everywhere.
Do 128 bits in many places out there.
but every new protocol is going to have problems.
And they'll come out with it at some point.
We're now having a new resource record in DNS.
If you're not familiar with DNS,
there's A records for addresses and H-info
But they're going to return quad A records for 128 bits
because their addresses are now four times bigger.
that's how you get the name from the number.
there are different domain classes to go backwards.
It's kind of the same thing we did with the new domain class.
DNS, you know, I said something about renumbering,
where if I go from there to here,
from the east coast to the west coast,
From the east coast to the west coast,
I get a new IP number.
DNS needs to know now where my new number is
so that if anybody wants to send me addresses,
if I have a mail server set up,
it needs to know where to send it.
So DNS needs to know where the new renumbering is.
And DNS needs to be renumbered.
It's in the IETF and they've set out all these RFCs.
And if you go to IETF.org and look through them,
that's where the internet protocols are developed.
That people from all over get together
and they get in working groups.
And if you're interested in a certain protocol,
They have discussions and they have meetings
and working code and rough consensus.
They try to get the code to work
And that's how protocols are developed.
That's how the new IPv6 is going to be developed.
So if you have any problems with protocols
or want to get involved in it,
just go to IETF.org and check it out.
But people are putting it into place.
Site operators are putting it into place
They've got IPv6 network within the university.
So you're able to tack in and have islands.
And it's starting to come around.
But things still need to come around.

and all of a sudden the machine changes addresses?
It's kind of like when they first created stoplights,
And so we would go and all of a sudden

so we could have the tri-level buffer.
So the same kind of thing here
with the preferred length of how long
it's going to be around versus valid.

This thing is going to renumber soon.
if you ever do different addresses in the HTTP,
then you go, well, here's my, you know,
for a new protocol in there
